comment.body: @Krixano: Isn't AWS mainly something like a CDN for serving static files?

@mkg20001 already created somewhat a [GitHub-Clone](/1F7b27kT38nMYZQg7tvDr33qWDZQgwnQpw/), and there are many "Tubes" already, though they, as far as I know, mainly use [instant.io](https://instant.io) to serve the videos..

A multiplayer-game is very hard, as not all peers are synchronized at an instant, but maybe you could 'clone' something like [this](https://github.com/AnthyG/Da_Cards) (I started developing it, I believe almost 2 years ago or so, but haven't finished it yet,.. and no, it's not for ZeroNet)
There are some single-player games on [this Zite](/1RETRoPXWgnP5K5v7ggwBHTo7eyumPvq1)
@Krixano: Yeah, me too :/

@Krixano: Maybe you could add some type of "voting" to the Requests page, which could somewhat prioritize specific entries for you?

Also, I would like to know, how do you sort the entries?
Is there any pattern behind it, or do you just put them somewhere you think they are best :?
You could also introduce votes to the main page, so that they get a higher ranking..

@Krixano: Also, for the sake of having all data better sorted, you should maybe write all the accepted Zites into a seperate `data.json`-File and generate all the entries out of that....
Maybe actually just your one `data.json`-File.. *WOW*, **mind-blown**, this could be a bookmark-Zite, or in other words, a ***collective Search-engine***! x_O

@Krixano: Well, if you put all the "special data" (the list of already accepted Zites) into your own `data.json`-File, then you could even include them into the database.. 

This would require you, to include a 'unique' property in your own `data.json`-File, like e.g. `accepted_zites`.
That could then contain all the Zites, you already accepted. Then you would have to create another table in the `dbschema.json`-File, and map the `accepted_zites`-Node from your own `data.json`-File to that table.

I'm not sure, if ZeroNet has the ability to generate multiple Databases yet.

@Krixano: As you have put the Zite on GitHub, I may eventually help you a little bit :)

Also, another recommendation would be, to add this `|^.git` to the `ignore`-Property of your Zites `content.json`-File, to exclude all `.git`-Files/ the `.git`-Directory

@Krixano: Add this line to your Zites `content.json`-File for responsive web design: `"viewport": "width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0, shrink-to-fit=no"`.

I don't quite understand what you mean with "multiline navigation type thing", probably just ... multiple lines of categories stacked above each other, which, if you mean that, isn't really a good thing, as the page would just become cluttered and much to *high*.

A sidebar would have to be a separated scrolling-area, as it would make the Zite even *higher*. But I think, this is the best way..

But I have to say, I like those tabs xD
@Krixano: That could be a solution..!

@Krixano: I just checked the tabs that bulma provides, and they are actually responsive in terms of transforming into an horizontal-scrollable list..
So it's not *that* bad.

But the menu looks great too!
And in the end, it's your Zite, not mine, so you decide ;)
That does really look better!

The last update-time of a Zite is saved in the `modified`-Property in the Zites `content.json`-File.
The value is an Integer representing the number of seconds since 1 January 1970 00:00:00 UTC).. I believe..

I actually, just like an hour ago, tried the exact same thing for private chats in ThunderWave, and I don't think, that ZeroNet can even use other files than those of the users.. but I would rather ask @nofish for answering this :?

@Krixano: Yeah, I think it's either a bug, or it happens when you are in debug-mode, but I haven't really tested anything so don't trust me x'D

@nofish: maybe?
@Krixano: I'll fork your GitHub-Repo now,... when my GitHub-Client stops being sh*t x/
@Krixano: [I created a pull-request](https://github.com/krixano/ImportantZites/pull/1)
@Krixano: And currently working on search :D

@Krixano: Nice!
Also just added a search-function, so if you want, I can push that to my master-branch :?

(It searches client-side-only, meaning through the `allZites`-Array)

[Here's the branch on GitHub](https://github.com/AnthyG/ImportantZites/tree/search-feature)
@Krixano: Looks nice!
No, but I know, I should :/

Just a question, how are you adding the content?
Because it might be a good idea to make a sub-page for creators, where people can also vote on other peoples contents, and then there could also be a in-zite markdown-editor for creating the content.
And for the list shown in the screenshot, I would put 4. as 2., and 2. and 3. into one bigger topic "Creating a new Zite", which would be 3. then, and thus all following would go -1 in the index

So apparently, I can't really use ZeroCDN in ThunderWave, probably just because I'm to dumb right now, to do it, ~~but now I also can't get jQuery back into the all.js-File >:|~~ (<-- Finally fixed, ugh)

@Krixano: Ah ok.

I have to go to school one last time this year, so I'll be back later and think more about all the stuff :)

@Antyhrabia: Yes, of course!
There are still a lot of issues left on [the GitHub-Page](https://github.com/AnthyG/ThunderWave/issues), so I'll finish those, and maybe other people suggest more cool stuff as well, so I definitely won't stop development.
Doesn't have to be, you can still post stuff, and view everything, .. you downloaded before your internet went down. :)

Is the Zite already on ZeroNet?
And if so, would you mind sharing the link? (Doesn't have to be here, you could [send me a ZeroMail](/Mail.ZeroNetwork.bit/?to=glightstar@zeroid.bit) (but of course, I'm not forcing you :)).
Oh lol, saw this _after_ I [answered on the newer post](/Me.Mkg20001.bit/?Post/12h51ug6CcntU2aiBjhP8Ns2e5VypbWWtv/12gAes6NzDS9E2q6Q1UXrpUdbPS6nvuBPu/1500726096) xD
@Krixano: Noice :)
Yeah! :D
Shouldn't be that hard.. right?! xD

@Krixano: Hmm, if the routing could work without a reload of the page, the following could maybe work:
Using this, to get the stuff after `?`, without the `wrapper_nonce[STUFF]`
`document.location.search.replace(/wrapper_nonce=([A-Za-z0-9]+)/, "")`

And then save the current state, and use a function to update it, and then check again..
I dunno X_o

@Krixano: I basically meant, make a function which uses `wrapperPustState` to set the new url, and call a function which loads the page.
Then, when you reload the page/ open it some other time/ somewhere else, call the load-function.
Then you could use the `getParameterByName`-function I sent you somewhere else.. probably on GitHub.., to check "the url".

So the page would always just be something like `?P:About`
.. You could probably also create a custom function based on `getParameterByName`, which uses `.split('/')` somewhere at the end of the `href`-thingy, to get an array of sub-pages, e.g.: `?P:About/WhoAmI`, which would return `["About", "WhoAmI"]`.

@Krixano: Now that I have a clear(er) head, I actually remembered that if the url of an iframe changes, the iframe reloads completely.
So this is _kinda_ a good thing. Though, as you say, it also prevents the location from updating..
@Krixano: So I believe you have to use `window.location`, .. if I'm correct, because that would use the windows url, not the documents, which AFAIK would refer to the iframe's url.

@Krixano: Then just call the load-function again x)
.. I have no other idea for now.. >:|
@Krixano: Good question, I'll look into it in a moment.
@Krixano: I went through quite a lot of code in ZeroMe, ZeroMail, and others sooo I'm quite good in understanding it >:>

So here's the routing:
https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroMe/blob/master/js/ZeroMe.coffee#L73

@Krixano: Well, the cloning could be done via a electron app, which accesses the data from ZeroNet (of course, meaning that the ZeroNet-Client has to be running). But the code for offline-stuff could be in that client as well..
And, in theory, this would also mean, that the same code could be used in any browser!

@Krixano: I know how to do the electron-stuff somewhat well.
But what I actually meant, you could still just do the coding for ZeroNet in the browser, as the code for the client is basically the same, except for syncing.
@Glightstar: There could also be something like an API on a zite, to which that client then connects..

@Krixano: Ah yeah, a plugin could do the client-side-stuff as well.
I rather thought about using electron/nodejs to do the client-side-stuff

@Krixano: I didn't think about communicating with the ZeroNet-Client directly, but rather just to do ajax-calls to zites, while the client is running, and if it's not running, the changes would just be local..
I haven't really checked into the client as-it.

@Krixano: Oh, that's a bit more then x_O

I do hate some browsers that want to make money with the open source technology, but I really love Electron.
I mean, I haven't yet managed to make something "great", or at least "good", but it's just soooo awesome :D

Well, are they public on Medium.com? :D
(Not a rhetorical question)

A, it does say "Your Medium _private_ bookmarks" at https://medium.com/browse/bookmarks

@Krixano: But one good side in web is that _all_ client's can access stuff via _one single_ point, and (with responsive web-design) have the same UI/ UX (no UI and UX are not the same, I know)
When I bought my PC, it cost around 650€ with 8GB of RAM..

Also, I don't really support single-site Electron-Apps like just Slack or just whatever.. But I do support Apps that provide access to multiple sites, so for example Slack, Telegram-Web and so on.
I do also admit, that I just try those clients (though I did use [Franz](www.meetfranz.com) for quite some time), and never really use them a lot or that often at least.

And at the end, why are we discussing this at all (I'm not against a good discussion), because everybody can just decide for themselves if they rather want to use the Electron-App or the site (btw. Electron-Apps also have the pro-side of serving everything from the disk, so you don't have to download "that" much every time you visit the site)
